author: pipermerriam
content:
Rough numbers for us to expect once we have 64 shards:

```

    1.398.101 bytes/second on-chain (shards)
    4.7 GB storage / 80 days / validator
    123.7 GB storage / 80 days / node
    36864000 shard blocks / 80 days
    9.4 TB / 80 days in unique data (unextended)
```

author: pipermerriam
content: 1 million nodes, each offering 100mb of storage.... > 95 TB -> replication factor of 10 -> 9.5 TB of available storage

author: pipermerriam
content: So it takes us a million nodes to make an Eth1 archive node....  or to house a rolling window of the last 80 days of block data ....   this still doesn't touch the state numbers for shards....

author: samwilsn
content: Oof

author: samwilsn
content: Wait, that's 9.4 TB, every 80 days, just for the blocks?

author: djrtwo
content:
(1) shards don't have state, they are data avaialbility machines
(2) incentive mechanisms only provide guarantees that shard blocks are available to network on that 80 day range
(3) responsibilities to store that data by consensus participants (validators) is sharded. In current designs, a single validator would only store 1/2048 of that 80 day shard history (4.5GB)

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!301186049323958275> I don't actually see this as bad.  If this roadmap for ultra-light client infrastructure yields the expected result, 1-million nodes should be a reasonable mark to hit.  Also, it may be reasonable for nodes to offer >100MB which could greatly expand how much storage the network has....  Basically, the numbers aren't that far off from "we could reasonably support the data requirements with the expected size of the network"

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!491624610215886849> and <@!425615769280315392> sounds like you two should talk with each other about Rust+DiscV5

author: pipermerriam
content: Just got off a 1:1 call with <@!514629735339261993> .  We talked a bit more about the idea of using an implementation of the uTP protocol over DiscV5 instead of libp2p.  I'm not sold that this is the right path forward, but I think it's worth investigating because there's something really nice about being able to do everything over DiscV5.  Especially when we get to chain history where the data we're transferring will regularly exceed the UDP packet size.  It seems like we should be able to implement an equivalent gossip network using this approach without needing libp2p at all.

author: pipermerriam
content: The experiment to validate this would likely be for someone to actually implement this on DiscV5 and measure throughput rates.

author: pipermerriam
content: Also, the inherent congestion control seems like a really nice feature since we're talking about these clients being lightweight and unobtrusive as always on processes.
